column8: abstract.en
Ctesiphon was the imperial capital of the Sasanian Empire. Joh. Eph., EH 3.40 and 6.10 does not use the name Ctesiphon, but refers to it as the 'royal city'.

Located in Roman Mesopotamia close to the Persian border, Dara was built by the emperor Anastasius in the early 6th century as a fortress city to confront the Persian stronghold of Nisibis. The fall of the city to the Persians in 573 reportedly triggered Justin's lapse into madness. The Persian siege of the city is described in Joh. Eph., EH 6.5.
The mountainous region of Hakkari in what is today southeast Turkey is also known as Qarhe in Syriac and mentioned in Joh. Eph., EH 6.9.
The city of Rusafa in the Syrian desert became known as Sergiopolis in Late Antiquity because of the martyr Sergius. Joh. Eph., EH 6.4 refers to it under its former name Rusafa.
Shura was a fortress town in the province of Syria Euphratensis west of Callinicum.

Hawran, also called Haurin, is a mountainous region in southern Syria. Joh. Eph., EH 3.40, mentions that Magnus, an official who held high ranks under Justin II and Tiberius, was a native of this region.

Arzun was the capital of the Armenian districut of Arzanene on the border zone between the Armenian highlands and upper Mesopotamia. Joh. Eph., EH 6.34, records the Roman conquest of the city in the early 580s.
The capital of the province Helenopontus, Amaseia was the see of a metropolitan and an important center in Late Antique Asia Minor.
A town in Roman Mesopotamia. Its surroundings were pillaged by the Persians under Adarmahan in the 570s, as recorded in Joh. Eph., EH 6.13.

Founded in the second half of the fifth century by the eponymous monk, this anti-Chalcedonian monastery, located close to the cities Callinicum and Sura on the Euphrates, was the abode of the bishop John of Sura in the 560s and 570s, as is attested in Joh. Eph., EH 4.22. In 581, the episcopal ordination of Peter of Callinicum took place there.

An important garrison town on the eastern border, the city was founded by Theodosius II in the first half of the 5th century. Its fortifications were further enlarged by Anastasius and Justinian, and it was the residence of the Roman military commander of Armenia. Joh. Eph., EH 2.20, mentions the patricius Justinian, a cousin of Justin II, in this role in the early 570s.

An important Christian pilgrimage site in late antiquity as it was believed to be the place where Moses received the ten commandments from God. Justinian erected a fortified monastic complex between 548 and 565. Gregory, patriarch of Antioch from 570 to 592, was archimandrite of this monastery prior to his accession as patriarch.

The city of Heliopolis, in Syriac-Armaic known as Baalbek, housed one of the largest pagan cult centres in the eastern Mediterranean. Among late antique Christian authors, it was famous for the obstinacy with which the majority of the inhabitants clung to pagan rites. For instance, Joh. Eph., EH 3.27 mentions the dispatch of the imperial official Theophilus in 579/80 to lead an investigation against pagans in the city.
A city in western Asia Minor.
A region in the southern Levant, in Late Antiquity subdivided in several provinces also called Palestine.
An island in the eastern Mediterranean, Cyprus was organised as a Roman province.
The region around the Nile valley, one of the richest and most fertile parts of the Roman Empire.
A region beyond the south-eastern borders of the Roman Empire, parts of it were incorporated in the empire and formed a province of the same name.
The Syriac name "the Land of the Arameans" corresponded to the Persian province of Asorestan in central Mesopotamia, the region around Babylon.
Sebasteia, modern Sivas, was the metropolis of the late Roman province of Armenia prima. In 575/6, it was sacked by a Persian army under Khosrow himself, as recorded in Joh. Eph., EH 6.8.
A region in the south of Asia minor, between Lycia and Cilicia.
Located at the entrance to the Peloponnese, Corinth was the metropolis of the Roman province of Achaea.
The region located at the southern end of the Balkan Peninsula.
This monastery was located in north-western Syria, about 30 km from Chalcis. The miaphysite bishop John of Chalcis probably resided there, as is recorded in Joh. Eph., EH 4.10.

An important imperial residence close to the Danube in Pannonia in the 4th century, Sirmium fell to Gothic and Gepid groups in the 5th century. The Romans reconquered it in the late 560s, but it definitely fell to the Avars in the early 580s, as recorded in Joh. Eph., EH 6.32 and 33.
A city in Caria in south-western Anatolia.
A city in Caria in south-western Anatolia.
A region in the western part of Anatolia, also the name of a Roman province.
The Syriac name for the region of Anzitene in southern Armenia. The miaphysite bishop George, mentioned in Joh. Eph., EH 4.10, hailed from this place.
A region in southern Armenia, often called Beth Urtaye in Syriac. The miaphysite bishop George, mentioned in Joh. Eph., EH 4.10, hailed from this place.
A region of central Anatolia which was subdivided in several provinces in Late Antiquity.

A monastery located on the seacoast, at the border between Egypt and Syria. Joh. Eph., EH 4.33, states that Jacob Burd'oyo and several of his companions died there in summer 578 when traveling to Egypt.
An imperial palace in Constantinople, built in the 5th century directly to the south-west of the Great Palace.
A mountainous region of southern Anatolia known for its warlike and often rebellious population.
The region of northern Africa to the east of Egypt, including the Cyrenaica.

A monastery and pilgrimage centre about 60 km south-west of Alexandria in the Mareotis region. During the 5th and 6th centuries, the monastery developed into one of the largest monastery complexes in Egypt.
One of the provinces into which Roman Egypt was subdivided, the Thebais formed the southern part of Egypt.
A region in south-eastern Europe, Thrace was in Late Antiquity the name of both a diocese and a province.
An important city in Late Antiquity in the region of Caria in western Asia minor.
The sea between Egypt/Nubia and Arabia is mentioned in Joh. Eph., EH 4.51 and 53.
Roman Africa was centred around its capital Carthage and one of the richest and most fertile regions of the empire.

This monastery, mentioned in Joh. Eph., EH 1.15 as a place of imprisonment for miaphysite clerics, is probably identical with the monastery founded by Abraham, archbishop of Ephesus, at the start of the sixth century. It was located in Constantinople close to the Theodosian walls at the Golden Gate.

Famous for their perpetual worship, the movement of the Acoemetae (sleepless monks), founded at the start of the 5th century, settled in a monastery on the Asian side of the Bosphorus around 430. The monks were staunchly dyophysite, to such an extent that they were suspected of harbouring Nestorian sympathies and condemned in the early 530s. Nevertheless, their monastery remained important and served as a place of imprisonment for miaphysite clerics, as is mentioned in Joh. Eph., EH 1.17.
Akbas was a Persian fortress on the river Batman close to Martyropolis in southern Armenia. Joh. Eph., EH 6.36, describes its capture and destruction by the Romans in 583.

A kingdom in northern Ethiopia that converted to Christianity in the early 4th century. Joh. Eph., EH 4.53, holds that the inhabitants of Aksum adhered to the doctrines of Julian of Halicarnassus in the later sixth century.

Alodia was a Nubian kingdom located to the south of Nobadia and Makouria. Joh.Eph., EH 4.48-53, narrates the missionary work of the miaphysite bishop Longinus there in the late 570s. In 4.53 and 55, John adds that Alodia was also known under the name Ethiopia (ܐܬܝܘܦܝܐ).
Anchialus, modern Pomorie in Bulgaria, was a city in Thrace on the west coast of the Black Sea.

The Sasanian king Khosrow built a new city close to his capital Ctesiphon for the Roman civilians he deported into his empire. Founded soon after the sack of Antioch in 540, he called it 'the better Antioch of Khosrow'. Joh. Eph., EH 6.19, reports that Roman prisoners were still brought there in the late 570s.

Aphum was a fortification in the Roman-Persian border area in southern Armenia to the east of Martyropolis and the river Batman. Joh. Eph., EH 6.34, records that Maurice conquered it from the Persians in 578.
A city in Cappadocia, it was the hometown of emperor Maurice (582-602), who embellished it with the construction of representative builidings, as is stated in Joh. Eph., EH 5.22 and 23.
A town in Cilicia. Joh. Eph., EH 5.4, mentions that the tritheist bishop Conon lived in a female monastery there in the mid-570s.
The Batman, in antiquity known as Kalat in Syriac and Nymphaios in Greek, is a tributary of the Tigris. It is mentioned in Joh. Eph., EH 6.36.
A region and Roman province in north-western Asia Minor.

One of the major churches of Antioch, the church of Cassian was repeatedly restored in the 6th century and lavishly decorated by Justinian. According to Joh. Eph., EH 4.41, Damian of Alexandria attempted to consecrate a new miaphysite patriarch there in early 580, but was prevented from doing so by the Chalcedonian patriarch Gregory.

Joh. Eph., EH 2.46, names thus the place in Bithynia, located close to the thermal baths of Pythia, where Narses gave the 'Kathara monastery' mentioned in Joh. Eph., EH 1.39, to a group of expelled miaphysite monks from Cappadocia. The name is not attested otherwise and may be connected to the Marcionite heretic Cerdon.

column4: Chalkoprateion, Church of the blessed Theotokos of the
column8: Built in the late fifth century, this church was located close to Hagia Sophia and was one of the four patriarchal churches of Constantinople. It housed one of the most important relics, the girdle of the Virgin Mary.
column11: Church of the Virgin in the Coppermarket

column8: Chlomaron was a Persian fortress in Armenia close to the border with the Roman Empire and adjacent to the fortress of Aphum. Joh. Eph., EH 6.34, records that Maurice failed to take this fortress during his campaign in 578.

The ecclesiastical centre of the patriarchate of Antioch, the great main church of Antioch was originally erected in the time of Constantine and underwent several restorations in the following centuries due to damage sustained in the frequent earthquakes which hit the city.
A fortress in the Roman part of Armenia close to Theodosiopolis and Persarmenia. Joh. Eph., EH 6.14, mentions this place.

Attested in Joh. Eph., EH 2.45, this was the place where a miaphysite group opposed to the tritheist doctrines spreading in the 560s and 570s used to gather. The localisation of this place in Constantinople is unknown.

The Syrian holy man Isaac erected, in 382, the first monastery in Constantinople. Isaac's successor as superior was Dalmatus, after whom the monastery was named. Its great importance is reflected by the fact that its superior was an archimandrite, who also acted as supervisor of all other monasteries in Constantinople. The monastery was a bastion of Chalcedonian orthodoxy and Joh. Eph., EH 2.9, mentions it as a place of confinement for high-ranking miaphysites in the early 570s.
A river in central and south-eastern Europe, formerly known as the Istros. Joh. Eph., EH 6.24 and 31, mentions this river.
Daphne was an opulent western suburb of Antioch. There were large residential areas and a number of important churches.
This settlement, mentioned in Joh. Eph., EH 3.8, as the place of origin of Ino Anastasia, is tentatively identified with the island of Daphnusia off the Black Sea coast of Bithynia.

A monastery founded by John of Ephesus in the mountains close to the city of Tralles during his missionary campaigns, as is narrated in Joh. Eph., EH 3.36 and 3.37. This monastery, erected on the foundations of a destroyed large pagan temple, is not attested in any other source.
A quarter of Constantinople comprising those areas located to the north of the Church of the Apostles and between the walls of Constantine and those of Theodosius.

Founded by a Syrian monk called Dios towards the end of the fourth century, one of the oldest monasteries in Constantinople. Its localisation is unknown, but Joh. Eph., EH 1.15, mentions that it served as a place of imprisonment for miaphysite clerics.

Founded in the 4th century, Dvin was the capital of Armenia. After the loss of the Armenian independence and the partition of the region between Rome and the Sasanian Empire, Dvin became the residence of the Sasanian governor of Persarmenia. Joh. Eph., EH 2.18-22, deals with the Sasanian persecution of the Armenian Christians that took place there in the early 570s.

Located to the north-east of Hagia Sophia, this hospice dates back to at least the start of the sixth century. Destroyed during the Nika riots in 532, it was rebuilt and served as place of confinement for John of Ephesus in 571/572, as is narrated in Joh. Eph., EH 2.4-7.

Having suffered martyrdom in the Galerian persecution around 303, Euphemia was venerated as saint. A church was constructed above her tomb in Chalcedon within some decades of her death. The council of Chalcedon took place in this church in 451 and it was eventually destroyed during the Persian siege of 626. Joh. Eph., EH 1.41, notes that Paul the Jew, patriarch of Antioch 519-521, had been presbyter at this church.
Located between the hippodrome and the forum of Constantine, this church was erected by Tiberius, as is mentioned in Joh. Eph., EH 3.24.
column25: Eglise des Quarante-Martyrs de la Mésé

column8: The Gepids were an east Germanic people who, after the dissolution of the Hunnic dominion in the mid-fifth century, established an independent kingdom centred around Sirmium on the central Danube. Their kingdom was destroyed in a joint attack by Lombards and Avars in 567.

The Great Palace was the residential complex of the East Roman emperors throughout Late Antiquity. Located at the south-eastern end of Constantinople, it consisted of several palaces and witnessed continuous building activity.

Joh. Eph., EH 2.46, is the earliest source to mention this monastery in Cappadocia. Its miaphysite inhabitants were forced to leave in the persecution of the 520s/530s and eventually received a new abode in Bithynia from the general Narses.

The monumental main church of Constantinople was destroyed during the Nika riots in 532, then rebuilt by Justinian on an even greater scale. Known as the Great Church, it played a major role in imperial ceremonies throughout the Byzantine period.

The Hebdomon was a coastal suburb located seven miles to the west of Constantinople. In Late Antiquity, it possessed an important imperial residence and large parade grounds for the army, hence it was also referred to in Greek as πρόκενσον (prokenson). Emperors were, upon their accession, acclaimed by the army on the parade ground of the Hebdomon in the later fourth and fifth centuries.

Metropolis of the Late Roman province Europa in Thrace, its significance dwindled in Late Antiquity because of the rise of Constantinople which was located only 90km to the east. Joh. Eph., EH 1.9, mentions it as a place of exile for miaphysites.
Joh. Eph., EH 6.5, notes that among the Roman fortifications of Dara, there was a tower which was larger than the others, called tower of Hercules.

Name of a palace in the Zeugma quarter of Constaninople close to the Golden Horn. Joh. Eph., EH 5.18, records that the emperor Maurice gave this palace to his sister Gordia and her husband Philippicus.
The great hippodrome of Constantinople was situated directly adjacent to the imperial palace. This was one of the few places where the people could interact with the emperor via acclamations.

The exact location of this monastery is uncertain. Its name is probably derived from a person called Katharas, not from the Greek "katharos", "pure" (by mistake leading to "Monastery of the pure"). As narrated in Joh. Eph., EH 1.39 and 2.46, the monastey was founded by the general Narses in Bithynia before he set off to Italy in the early 550s, thus providing an abode for miaphysite monks who had been expelled from Cappadocia. After his death, Narses was buried in this monastery.

The Long Walls were erected in the early sixth century during the reign of Anastasius. They stretched 58 km from the Black Sea to the Sea of Marmara and guarded the western approach to Constantinople, more than 70 km to the west of the city.
A kingdom located in Nubia, situated between the kingdoms of Nobadia and Alodia. Joh. Eph., EH 4.51 and 53, speaks of the people of Makouria.
A district and town to the south-west of Alexandria, famous for its freshwater lake.

Constructed in the fifth century as residence for Marina, daughter to the emperor Arcadius, the palace became part of the imperial estate after her death. Joh. Eph., EH 3.16, records that anti-Chalcedonians used to gather there for worship.
A church in north-western Constantinople. Joh. Eph., EH 2.16, mentions a priest named Comitas who was part of the clergy of this church.
column11: Basilica of the Virgin Mary of Blachernai

column8: The monumental complex of the Nea Church in Jerusalem, dedicated to the Mother of God, included a monastery and was founded by Justinian in 543. Joh. Eph., EH 1.32, mentions that Photius, stepson of Belisarius, was abbot of the monastery belonging to the church.
A kingdom in Nubia, situated between Roman Egypt and the kingdom of Makouria. Joh. Eph., EH 4.5-9, records the activities of miaphysite missionaries in Nobadia.

The residence of the patriarchs of Constantinople was adjacent to Hagia Sophia and provided direct access to the south-western corner of the church. Joh. Eph., EH 1.18-29, mentions it as the place where he and other miaphysite bishops were imprisoned and forced to accept an edict of union with the Chalcedonians.
The exact location of the episcopal residence in Antioch is unknown, yet it was in close proximity to the Great Church.

Originally an independent kingdom situated between the Roman and Sasanian Empires, Armenia was divided between the two powers in the late 4th century. Almost four-fifths came under Sasanian dominion, and this part, with Dvin as its capital, is known as Persarmenia or Sasanian Armenia. Joh. Eph., EH 2.18-22, deals with the Sasanian persecution of the Armenian Christians in the early 570s.
column11: Armenia (Persarmenia has not its own article), cp. Duin

column8: Located on an island in the First Nile Cataract, Philae was a major cultic centre for the goddess Isis. Traces have been unearthed that pagan rituals took place there until the mid-5th century, yet already since the early 4th century, Philae was also an episcopal see.

This palace was built in the fifth century as a residence for Galla Placidia, daughter to Theodosius I. It was located in the north-western part of Constantinople, close to the Golden Horn, and later served as a residence for the apocrisiarius, the ambassador, of the bishop of Rome.

The modern Yassiada, one of the Princes' Islands close to Constantinople where recalcitrant clerics were frequently sent into exile in Late Antiquity and the Byzantine period. Joh. Eph., EH 1.16, notes that the miaphysite bishop Stephen of Cyprus was maltreated there.

column4: The Praetorium of the Praetorian Prefect
column8: The residence of the Praetorian Prefect of the East, an official overseeing the administration of the whole Roman east and serving as first minister to the emperor.

column4: The Praetorium of the Urban Prefect
column8: The residence of the urban prefect in Constantinople, responsible for all aspects of government in the capital.
Joh. Eph., EH 3.29 mentions that Anatolius, convicted of being a pagan, was brought to the residence of the governor of Syria Prima. The exact location of this structure in Antioch is unknown.
The residence of Anatolius, governor or the Roman province of Osrhoene, was in Edessa and is mentioned in Joh. Eph., EH 3.28.

Joh. Eph., EH 2.46, mentions that the Kathara monastery given to a group of expelled miaphysite monks from Cappadocia was close to the therms of Pythia in Bithynia. This was a very popular spa resort for people from Constantinople, including the imperial court, throughout the Byzantine period.

Joh. Eph., EH 2.13, is the only source for the existence of this monastery in Late Antiquity. John Mauropous, an author of the 11th century, notes that it was founded around 490 and that it was located close to the Theodosian walls and the Gate of St Romanus (now Topkapi).

According to Joh. Eph., EH 4.10, Longinus and two other bishops ordained, with the consent of Paul the Black of Antioch, Theodore as new patriarch of Alexandria in 575. Theodore was archimandrite of a monastery called Rhamnis in the Scete region south-west of Alexandria.

Situated to the north of Jerusalem, Samaria formed the core of the ancient kingdom of Israel. Its inhabitants, the Samaritans, preserved their religious customs in Late Antiquity and repeatedly revolted against the Roman Empire in the sixth century. Joh. Eph., EH 2.29, polemically establishes a connection between Samaritans and persecutors of Christians.

One of the largest guesthouses and hospitals supporting the poor in Constantinople, it was already fully functioning at the start of Justinian's reign. Located close to Hagia Sophia, it was destroyed during the Nika riots in 532, rebuilt and further endowed by the emperor. Joh. Eph., EH 1.42, mentions that prior to his accession as patriarch, Menas of Constantinople (536-552) had been the leader of this hospice.
The capital of Lydia, Sardis was one of the most important cities in Asia Minor throughout Antiquity and into the Byzantine period.

According to Joh. Eph., EH 6.35, Maurice, as commander of the Roman forces in the east, erected a fortress called Semkhart next to a mountain with the same name in the Armenian region of Sophanene in the early 580s. The place is called Samocharta in the Greek sources.

The centre of the cult of the martyr saint Sergius in Rusafa, renamed Sergiopolis, since the early 5th century. A large, representative basilica was probably erected in the early 6th century. The cult of Sergius was especially popular among the Arab tribes, as is attested in Joh. Eph., EH 6.4.

While there is some debate as to whether Justinian started the construction of this church before or after his accession to the imperial throne in 527, it was certainly completed by the mid-530s. It was located to the south-west of the Great Palace, directly adjacent to the Hormisdas Palace. There also was a monastery which housed many miaphysite monks and clerics during the 530s and 540s.
column11: Church of Ss. Sergius and Bacchus
column22: Μονὴ τῶν ἁγίων Σεργίου καὶ Βάκχου

column8: This monastery, located in Constantinople, is only attested in Joh. Eph., EH 4.38. He records that the archpriest Theodosius, one of the most important miaphysite clerics in Alexandria, was imprisoned there in 579 for religious disputations with patriarch Eutychius. Theodosius died during his stay in this monastery.
A village 60km southeast of Antioch. John III Scholasticus, patriarch of Constantinople 565-577, hailed from this place.
Sophanene was the name of a region in the southern part of Armenia, not to be confused with the neighbouring Sophene.

column4: Theotokos in Tella, Church of the
column8: Joh. Eph., EH 6.13, notes that there was a large church dedicated to the Virgin Mary outside the city walls of Tella. It was destroyed when the Persians under Adarmahan pillaged the region in the 570s.

One of the most important Roman cities on the Balkan peninsula, Thessalonica was provincial capital of Macedonia prima and the administrative center of the whole Illyrian prefecture. Prior to the rise of Constantinople, it was even imperial capital during parts of the 4th century.

Joh. Eph., EH 6.26, records that the Persian army retreated to a small river after their defeat at Tella in June 582. Michael Whitby has identified this river as the Wadi Dara (also called Wadi Jarrah), a tributary of the Khabur close to Dara.
A quarter of Constantinople extending from the valley between the third and fourth hill to the Golden Horn.

Situated very close to the Great Palace, Hagia Sophia and the hippodrome, the baths of Zeuxippus were the most famous public baths of Constantinople. Throughout Late Antiquity, emperors brought statues and other renowned works of art to Constantinople, many of which were put on display in the baths of Zeuxippus. The baths were burned down in 532 during the Nika riots and rebuilt by Justinian I. Joh. Eph., EH 3.24, refers to the eastern part of the city near the seashore by the name Zeuxippus, likely because of the prominence of the baths.

column4: The first miaphysite diaconate in Constantinople
column6: The first miaphysite diaconate in Constantinople
column8: Joh. Eph., EH 2.15, mentions a diaconate which was, under the leadership of a certain Thallus, run by many miaphysite clerics and monastics.

column4: The second miaphysite diaconate in Constantinople
column6: The second miaphysite diaconate in Constantinople
column8: Joh. Eph., EH 2.16, mentions another diaconate, led by a certain Comitas, which was dissolved during the miaphysite persecution in the 570s.
Joh. Eph., EH 3.15, states that John of Ephesus was imprisoned at this place in Constantinople for 18 days during Christmas 578.

column4: The former residence of Justin II
column6: The former residence of Justin II
column8: According to Joh. Eph., EH 3.24, Justin lived in a house in the north-west of Constantinople prior to his accession to the imperial throne. Later he erected a large palace there, for which many houses had to be torn down.

According to Joh. Eph., EH 5.16, the Arian inhabitants of Constantinople used to assemble in a palace or court given to them by an anonymous empress outside the city. The exact location and identity of this place remain unknown.

Joh. Eph., EH 5.18, records that Maurice presented his widowed sister Theoctista with a great mansion upon his accession. This residence had first belonged to Peter Barsymes. Its exact location in Constantinople is unknown.

column4: The thermal baths of Justin II
column6: The thermal baths of Justin II
column8: Possibly identical with the therms of Pythia mentioned in Joh. Eph., EH 2.46.

column4: The villa of John of Ephesus
column6: The villa of John of Ephesus
column8: John of Ephesus had received a villa as gift from the praepositus sacri cubiculi Callinicus. He narrates in EH 2.41 that he spent a lot of money for turning this villa into a monastery, but also that he had to give it up during the persecution of the 570s.
Eutychius spent his exile from 565 to 577 in his old monastery in Amaseia where he had dwelt prior to his accession to the patriarchate in 552.
column11: Monastery of Seleucus, Meletius and Uranius

column8: Joh. Eph., EH 6.7, records how 2000 Christian Roman women, sent as a gift by Khosrow to the Turks, decided to drown themselves in a broad river. The river might have been the Oxus or the Jaxartes in central Asia.

column4: The residence of Anatolius in Antioch
column6: The residence of Anatolius in Antioch
column8: Anatolius also had a residence in Antioch where he frequently dwelt, as is mentioned in Joh. Eph., EH 3.29.
